items.title: China places two top generals under investigation in major purge

featured_image.name: China's Xi Places His Top General Under Investigation as ...

items.description:
China's highest-level military purge in decades became official on January 24, 2026, when state media confirmed that Zhang Youxia, vice chairman of the Central Military Commission and a member of the ruling Politburo, has been placed under investigation for "serious violations of discipline and law." Liu Zhenli, chief of the Joint Staff Department and a CMC member, is also being investigated, according to an announcement from the Ministry of National Defense.[1][2][3]

The terse statement said the decision to open investigations into both senior military figures followed "deliberation by the Party's central leadership," providing no further details on the alleged violations.[4][5]

items.title: Gold crosses $5,000 per ounce for the first time

featured_image.name: Gold smashes new record of $4,600 as Powell probe and global flashpoints ignite safe-haven rush

items.description:
Gold prices have breached the closely watched $5,000-per-ounce barrier for the first time, capping a historic rally fueled by a weakening U.S. dollar, robust central bank buying, and expectations of further Federal Reserve rate cuts.

As of Saturday, January 24, 2026, spot gold traded at approximately $4,988 per ounce after establishing an intra-day record high above $5,009 earlier in the session. The precious metal has gained roughly 15% since the start of 2026 and nearly 80% compared to a year ago. Silver has been equally buoyant, with prices approaching $100 per ounce after hitting unprecedented highs in recent sessions.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Trump threatens 100% tariffs if Canada proceeds with China deal

featured_image.name: Trump imposes promised tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Saturday threatened to impose a 100 percent tariff on all Canadian goods entering the United States if Canada proceeds with its newly signed trade agreement with China, dramatically escalating a week of diplomatic tensions with America's northern neighbor.

"If Governor Carney thinks he is going to make Canada a 'Drop Off Port' for China to send goods and products into the United States, he is sorely mistaken," Trump wrote on Truth Social, referring to Prime Minister Mark Carney. "China will eat Canada alive, completely devour it, including the destruction of their businesses, social fabric, and general way of life."[1][2]

items.title: Chinese scientists achieve 10x boost in CO2-to-starch conversion

featured_image.name: Chinese scientists turn carbon dioxide to starch with 10 ...

items.description:
Researchers at China's Tianjin Institute of Industrial Biotechnology have increased the productivity of their carbon dioxide-to-starch conversion technology by more than tenfold compared to their original 2021 breakthrough, according to a report published Friday by the Chinese Academy of Sciences-run China Science Daily.[1][2][3]

The advance brings scientists closer to industrializing a process that could fundamentally reshape how one of the world's most important carbohydrates is produced, potentially eliminating the need for agricultural cultivation of corn and other starchy crops.

items.title: Methane-eating bacteria could turn pollution into plastics, study finds

featured_image.name: Meet The Microbes That “Eat” Harmful Methane Pollution

items.description:
Bacteria that consume methane could transform one of the planet's most potent greenhouse gases into useful products including biodegradable plastics, animal feed, and cleaner fuels, according to a new scientific review examining rapid advances in methanotroph research.

The study, published this week in the journal Energy & Environment Nexus, positions methane-consuming bacteria as biological "gatekeepers" capable of both reducing climate-warming emissions and converting waste gases into valuable materials.[1][2][3]

items.title: UK-led mission to create artificial eclipses proposed to ESA

featured_image.name: Proposed new mission will create artificial solar eclipses in space

items.description:
An international consortium of scientists has proposed a spacecraft mission to generate artificial solar eclipses in space, offering unprecedented views of the Sun's atmosphere as Earth experiences its most severe solar radiation storm in over two decades.

The Moon-Enabled Sun Occultation Mission, known as Mesom, has been submitted to the European Space Agency for consideration as a future mission. If approved, the mini-satellite would position itself within the Moon's shadow roughly once every 29.6 days, creating total eclipse conditions lasting up to 48 minutes—ten times longer than typical eclipses observed from Earth.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Pentagon says South Korea will lead North Korea deterrence

featured_image.name: Aerial View of the Pentagon

items.description:
The Pentagon on Friday unveiled its National Defense Strategy, outlining a fundamental change in how the United States approaches security on the Korean Peninsula: South Korea will now be expected to take the lead in deterring North Korea, with Washington providing "more limited" support.

"South Korea is capable of taking primary responsibility for deterring North Korea with critical but more limited U.S. support," according to the document released Friday evening, as reported by Reuters. "This shift in the balance of responsibility is consistent with America's interest in updating U.S. force posture on the Korean Peninsula."[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Iran warns any US attack will be treated as 'all-out war'

featured_image.name: Trump Renews Iran Threats, Says Navy 'Armada' Heading to ...

items.description:
Iran declared Friday that any military attack on its territory will be treated as "all-out war," issuing its starkest warning yet as a US aircraft carrier strike group steams toward the Middle East amid heightened tensions over the country's deadly crackdown on nationwide protests.

"Any attack, limited or otherwise, will be treated as an all-out war against us, and we will respond in the hardest way possible," a senior Iranian official told Reuters, speaking on condition of anonymity. The warning came as Iranian forces remained on high alert ahead of the arrival of US military reinforcements in the region.[1][2]

items.title: Studies find AI language models mirror human brain in both processing and bias

featured_image.name: The human brain may work more like AI than anyone expected ...

items.description:
Two new studies reveal that the systems powering AI chatbots like ChatGPT and Gemini share unexpected parallels with the human brain—not just in how they build meaning from words, but also in how they absorb social biases.

Research published in Nature Communications found that the human brain processes spoken language through a stepwise sequence that closely mirrors the layered architecture of large language models (LLMs). A separate study from the University of Vermont, posted to the arXiv preprint server, shows that widely used AI models exhibit "us vs. them" social biases similar to patterns documented in human psychology.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Venezuela’s interim president says 626 prisoners freed but rights groups count 154

featured_image.name: Venezuela's Rodriguez vows release of more prisoners, holds call ...

items.description:
Venezuela's interim president Delcy Rodriguez announced on Friday that 626 individuals have been released from prison as part of an ongoing initiative, though human rights organizations dispute the official figure, confirming far fewer releases.

Rodriguez, who assumed interim leadership after U.S. forces captured former president Nicolas Maduro on January 3, made the announcement during the installation of a "Program for Coexistence and Peace" in Caracas. She did not provide a specific timeline for when these releases occurred.[1][2][3]

items.title: Gold nears $5,000 in best week since 2020 as silver tops $100

featured_image.name: S&P 500 ends Friday little changed, but posts second straight losing week amid wild trading

items.description:
Gold approached $5,000 per ounce on Friday, capping its strongest week since March 2020, while silver breached the $100 threshold for the first time and Intel shares tumbled more than 17%, dragging down U.S. markets to a muted close.

The precious metals surge came amid lingering geopolitical uncertainty, a weakening U.S. dollar, and investor demand for safe-haven assets. Meanwhile, Wall Street concluded a volatile week with all three major indexes posting losses, as the chipmaker's disappointing outlook underscored persistent challenges in the semiconductor industry.

items.title: Major airlines suspend Middle East flights amid US-Iran tensions

featured_image.name: Air France-KLM Halts Dubai, Riyadh Flights on Geopolitical ...

items.description:
KLM, Air France, Lufthansa, British Airways, Swiss, and several other major carriers abruptly suspended flights to Israel, the United Arab Emirates, and Saudi Arabia on Friday, citing escalating security concerns as U.S. President Donald Trump announced a naval "armada" heading toward Iran.

The coordinated cancellations, which began late Thursday evening and extended through the weekend, disrupted travel plans for thousands of passengers across Europe and left airports scrambling to manage the sudden disruption. The flight suspensions came as Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan warned that Israel continues to seek an opportunity to strike Iran.

items.title: Uganda military chief says 2,000 detained, 30 killed in post-election crackdown

featured_image.name: Uganda detains 2,000 opposition supporters, kills 30 after disputed election, army chief says

items.description:
Uganda's military chief announced Friday that authorities have detained 2,000 opposition supporters and killed 30 people in an escalating crackdown following last week's contested presidential election in which his father, President Yoweri Museveni, won a seventh term.

General Muhoozi Kainerugaba, who is also Museveni's son and widely believed to be his designated successor, disclosed the figures in a series of overnight social media posts, labeling members of the opposition National Unity Platform as "hooligans and terrorists." "So far we have killed 30 NUP terrorists," Kainerugaba wrote on X, without explaining the circumstances of the deaths. "Most NUP terrorist leaders are in hiding. We shall get them all," he added in another post.[1][2][3]

items.title: Zelensky urges caution after first day of Ukraine-Russia-US talks

featured_image.name: SWITZERLAND-POLITICS-ECONOMY-DIPLOMACY

items.description:
The first day of trilateral negotiations between Ukraine, Russia, and the United States concluded Friday in Abu Dhabi, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urging caution while the White House expressed measured optimism about the historic diplomatic effort.

"It is still too early to draw conclusions about the content of today's negotiations; we will see how the talks go tomorrow and what the results will be," Zelensky said in his nightly address. The Ukrainian leader noted his negotiating team had provided updates "almost every hour" throughout the day but offered no details about specific discussions or progress.[1][2][3]

items.title: Tech CEOs tout AI job creation at Davos as workers grow anxious

featured_image.name: SWITZERLAND-POLITICS-ECONOMY-DIPLOMACY

items.description:
Business leaders at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, projected optimism this week about artificial intelligence creating jobs despite stark warnings from global economic officials and rising worker anxiety about the technology's disruptive potential.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang emerged as a leading voice for AI optimism, telling attendees that the technology would generate employment across blue-collar trades. "Energy is creating jobs. Chips industry is creating jobs. The infrastructure layer is creating jobs," Huang said during a conversation with BlackRock CEO Larry Fink. "Jobs, jobs, jobs."[1][2]

Huang characterized the current AI buildout as "the largest infrastructure buildout in human history," predicting six-figure salaries for electricians, plumbers, and construction workers without needing "a Ph.D. in computer science."[3][4]

items.title: Trump says US military 'armada' is heading toward Iran

featured_image.name: US sending military assets to Middle East as Trump weighs Iran strike,  sources say

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Thursday that a US military "armada" is heading toward Iran, even as he expressed hope that the deployment would not be needed for further military action against Tehran.

"We have an armada. We have a massive fleet heading in that direction, and maybe we won't have to use it. We'll see," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One as he returned from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.[1][2][3]

The deployment includes the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, several guided-missile destroyers, and fighter aircraft, which began moving from the Asia-Pacific region last week, according to US officials speaking to Reuters. The carrier strike group is expected to arrive in the Middle East in the coming days, with officials also considering additional air defense systems to protect US forces and bases in the region.[4][5][6]

items.title: Davos forum ends with climate sidelined as U.S. pushes fossil fuels

featured_image.name: Five takeaways from Davos 2026 - Reuters

items.description:
As the World Economic Forum wrapped up its 56th Annual Meeting in Davos, Switzerland, on January 23, the gathering revealed a stark realignment: climate change discussions had retreated to the sidelines, while fossil fuels took center stage amid a fractured geopolitical landscape.

President Donald Trump's address on January 21 set the tone. "There are windmills all over Europe, and they are failures," Trump told the audience of global executives and policymakers, branding green initiatives "the Green New Scam." He promoted oil and nuclear power, claiming U.S. natural gas production had reached record highs and oil output had risen by 730,000 barrels per day.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump claim that NATO allies avoided Afghan frontlines sparks fury

featured_image.name: Starmer expresses U.K. outrage over Trump NATO Afghanistan comments

items.description:
President Donald Trump ignited fury across NATO allies on Thursday after claiming in a Fox News interview that troops from allied nations "stayed a little back, a little off the front lines" during the war in Afghanistan. The remarks drew immediate condemnation from British, Polish, Danish, and Canadian officials, as well as veterans who served in the conflict, prompting British Prime Minister Keir Starmer to call the comments "insulting and frankly appalling."[1][2]

Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Trump questioned whether NATO would support the United States if called upon. "We've never needed them. We have never really asked anything of them," Trump said. "They'll say they sent some troops to Afghanistan, and they did—they stayed a little back, a little off the front lines."[3][4]

items.title: Goldman Sachs raises gold price target above $5,000

featured_image.name: Goldman Raises Year-End Gold Forecast to $5,400 an Ounce

items.description:
Goldman Sachs upgraded its end-2026 gold price target to $5,400 per ounce from $4,900, a more than 10% increase, as the investment bank said private investors hedging global policy risks and emerging-market central banks diversifying reserves are reshaping demand dynamics for the precious metal.

The revision, contained in a research note dated January 21 by analysts Daan Struyven and Lina Thomas, positions gold for roughly 9% further upside from prices trading near $4,950 per ounce on Friday morning as the metal flirts with the $5,000 milestone.[1][2][3]

items.title: Climate talks take back seat at Davos as AI, geopolitics dominate

featured_image.name: 'I won't use force' for Greenland: Key takeaways from Trump's Davos ...

items.description: As global leaders gathered in Davos, Switzerland for the World Economic Forum's 56th Annual Meeting this week, climate change discussions that once dominated the gathering took a back seat to geopolitics, artificial intelligence, and economic competition. The shift reflects a broader recalibration among business and political leaders who increasingly prioritize adaptation over ambitious emissions reduction goals.
